action.action-desc: Ms. Pressley (for herself and Mr. Lynch) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Financial Services

form.official-title: To amend the Expedited Funds Availability Act to require that funds deposited be available for withdrawal in real-time, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Payments Modernization Act of 2023.

paragraph.text: Families in the United States spend billions of dollars in overdraft fees in part because they are waiting for checks to clear over a weekend or holiday.
The inefficient payment system in the United States drives families, especially those living paycheck to paycheck, to use high-cost financial services to access funds more rapidly.

A faster payment system would provide people of the United States immediate access to funds and relief for those who overdraw their accounts because their deposits are not available in real-time, helping families potentially save billions of dollars each year.
The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System has created FedNow, an instant payment infrastructure that allows participants to send and receive funds in real time.
Financial services providers have a duty to make payments available as soon as it is reasonably possible.

subsection.text: The purposes of this Act are—

paragraph.text: to ensure that the United States has a safe, fast, efficient, equitable, and fair payment system; and
to clarify that financial institutions shall prioritize efficient payments, except in cases in which fraudulent activity is suspected.

section.text: In this Act, the term real-time has the meaning given the term in section 602 of the Expedited Funds Availability Act (12 U.S.C. 4001), as amended by section 4(a) of this Act.

section.header: Requirement that funds deposited be available for withdrawal in real-time

paragraph.text: Section 602 of the Expedited Funds Availability Act (12 U.S.C. 4001) is amended—

subparagraph.text: by redesignating paragraphs (20) through (25) as paragraphs (21) through (26), respectively; and
by inserting after paragraph (19) the following:

paragraph.text: The term real-time—

subparagraph.text: includes a Saturday, Sunday, and a legal holiday.

paragraph.text: Section 3 of the Check Clearing for the 21st Century Act (12 U.S.C. 5002(2)(D)(iv)) is amended by striking section 602(24) and inserting section 602(25).

subparagraph.text: in the subsection heading, by striking Next Business Day and inserting Real-time;

clause.text: in the matter preceding subparagraph (A), by striking Except as provided in subsection (e) and in section 604, in and inserting In; and
in the matter following subparagraph (B) by striking not later than the business day after the business day on which and inserting in real-time when; and

subparagraph.text: in paragraph (2), in the matter preceding subparagraph (A), by striking not later than the business day after the business day on which and inserting in real-time after;

paragraph.text: by striking subsection (b) and inserting the following:

subsection.text: Funds deposited in an account at a depository institution by a check drawn on a local or nonlocal originating depository institution shall be available for withdrawal in real-time.

paragraph.text: by striking subsections (a) and (b); and
by redesignating subsections (c) through (f) as subsections (a) through (d), respectively.

subsection.text: Section 609 of the Expedited Funds Availability Act (12 U.S.C. 4008) is amended—

paragraph.text: in subsection (b)(8), by striking , pursuant to the study under subsection (f);
by striking subsections (d) and (f); and
by redesignating subsection (e) as subsection (d).

subsection.text: Not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General of the United States shall publish a study on the impact of payment delays on disadvantaged communities, including underbanked communities, and future access to and use of financial services by those communities.

Not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System shall submit to Congress a report on the progress of the FedNow instant payment infrastructure, including—

paragraph.text: any obstacles encountered with respect to institutions opting to utilize FedNow or participants using FedNow; and
any challenges anticipated with respect to expanding the utilization of FedNow.
